context.p: In DITA, indexes are created from indexterm elements. You can insert index term elements:

ul.li: In the header of a topic. In paginated media (such as a printed book or a PDF, this will result in an index entry that point to the page on which the topic starts, even if it is not the page on which the indexed term occurs.

In the topicref element in a map that references the topic. This will apply those index terms to that topic only when used in that map. This allows you to index topics differently in different publications. In paginated media, index entries will point to the page on which the topic starts.
In the body of a topic. In paginated media, this will result in an index entry that point to the page on which the indexterm element occurs, even if that is not the page on which the topic starts.

context.p: To add index terms to the text of a topic of the topic header, create the elements as you normally would in . To add index terms to a map, open the map in the editor and add the elements as you normally would in a topic.

In some media, indexes will be generated automatically when index entries are found in the source. For other media, such as books, you may need to tell DITA where to place the index. For instance, to add an index to a bookmap, you need to add an indexlist element to the backmatter of the book.

step.cmd: Open your bookmap in the DITA Maps Manager.
Right click on the book map icon and select Append Child Backmatter... . The Insert Reference dialog appears.
Press Insert and Close to insert the backmatter element.
Right click on the backmatter element and create a booklists element using Append Child Booklists... .
Use the same steps to create a indexlist element.

result.note: Adding index entries and an indexlist to you project creates an instruction to the DITA publishing routines to create an index. There is no guarantee that all DITA output types or third party customizations will obey that instruction or create the index the way you want it. Modifying the output may be necessary to get the result you want.
